title: Lucas Kook
text:
I am currently a postdoctoral researcher in statistics and causal inference at the Copenhagen Causality Lab. Together with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters, I work at the intersection of distributional regression and causal inference with a focus on biomedical applications.
In February 2023, I finished my PhD at the University of Zurich under the supervision of Beate Sick and Torsten Hothorn. My PhD research focused on combining distributional regression models with deep learning approaches and causal inference to improve treatment decisions for acute ischemic stroke patients.















New preprint 🎉 “Algorithm-agnostic significance testing in supervised learning with multimodal data” in collaboration with Anton Rask Lundborg. The corresponding comets R package is available on GitHub.
In March 2024, I will start my new role as assistant professor of statistics at the Institute for Statistics and Mathematics of the Vienna University for Economics and Business.
New preprint 🎉 “Model-based causal feature selection for general response types” in collaboration with Sorawit Saengkyongam, Anton Rask Lundborg, Torsten Hothorn and Jonas Peters. Software implementing our method is available as an R package (tramicp on GitHub and on CRAN).
I acquired a postdoctoral mobility grant from the Swiss National Science Foundation for my proposal on Distributional Instrumental Variables Estimation (DIVE). During the of the fellowship, I will be working with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters at the University of Copenhagen, starting March 2023.
I successfully defended my PhD thesis titled “Deep Learning and Causal Inference with Transformation Models” on February 8, 2023.
New preprint 🎉 “Estimating Conditional Distributions with Neural Networks using R package deeptrafo” with software available on CRAN.

title: About me
text:
I am currently a postdoctoral researcher in statistics and causal inference at the Copenhagen Causality Lab. Together with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters, I work at the intersection of distributional regression and causal inference with a focus on biomedical applications.
In February 2023, I finished my PhD at the University of Zurich under the supervision of Beate Sick and Torsten Hothorn. My PhD research focused on combining distributional regression models with deep learning approaches and causal inference to improve treatment decisions for acute ischemic stroke patients.
